text: First thanks everybody for staying I was kind of worried that everybody had gone home so thank you all for turning up So I'm going to be talking about supply chain security and kind of concrete lessons that we can learn from actual security incidents I've got a clicker I'll be professional One thing I kind of tend to worry a little bit about with security content like talks and blogs but also tooling to be honest is that we tend to focus on attacks and problems and detection but a little bit less on you know we kind of offer like vague and hand wavy advice on how to actually prevent future attacks That's probably something I've been guilty of in the past and I guess the thing is it's much easier to do a talk or a blog about an outrageous hack or some shocking statistics and things like that and turn that into sort of a compelling story and then you end with like a vague statement like check your sources or don't do that or implement zero trust And that doesn't really help people fix things And I kind of think we need to do a bit better than that as an And we should be pushing more concrete actionable advice that organizations can sort of immediately implement and use So we should be pressurizing organizations to take simple immediate actions things like implementing or enforcing multi factor authentication But yeah in this talk we'll be looking at actual incidents and what we can do to prevent attacks like those in the But first I do have a little bit of good news I gave you a slight preview there But I have gone through all the cybersecurity reports I could find And I think I've identified the person responsible for the vast majority of them Because it's always the same person It's this person And they are everywhere And I mean everywhere Now in most pictures and there's a lot of pictures so it's not very good operational security but in most pictures the face is obscured But in this picture they're using gloves which I think has to be a bit of a And like in all the other ones the hands are So I think in all the pictures they have And I do kind of wonder how you can type like that But I guess they're showing off And in some you do get a glimpse of the face Maybe it's a different one I In this one they have gloves and a magnifying glass It does slightly make me doubt their credentials to be But yeah if we arrest this person I'm pretty sure global cybercrime is going to drop off a Okay the boring slide I'm Adrian Moe I'm a DevRel engineer at Chainguard I did once write a book on I don't buy it because it's ten years out of date If you want to find me though it's actually quite easy because my name is relatively unusual But that QR code will take you No we'll share the slides later Okay so I'm going to go through about three incidents The first one I'm going to start with is CodeCov So this I mean in some ways it feels like a long time ago but it's not really I don't really think things have advanced that much since 2021 CodeCov is quite a useful service Basically what it does is it will report on how much of your source code is covered by tests So if somebody submits a PR you can figure out your test coverage goes up or Yeah so definitely useful but they had an incident And they didn't release full details of exactly what but from their blog and a few other things they kind of pieced it all together Definitely what happened was they published various Docker images And in one of those Docker images it turned out there was a secret that shouldn't have been there And that secret provided access to their Google Cloud Storage So attackers found that secret and they rifled through the cloud storage and they found the bash uploader script used by And this was the script that their customers would use to upload their own code to CodeCov for analysis that meant all the customers were running the script as part of the CICD And so what the attackers did was they just added one single line to that And all that line did was send all the environment variables to a server they controlled Now that might sound a bit innocuous because it's just environment variables but do remember that this is running in CICD So quite often in CICD pipelines people put secrets and stuff in the environment variables And now they're all being sent to this server controlled by And a lot of people had a pretty bad day And it included some pretty big customers like Twilio Confluent Rapid7 and HashiCorp And some of these customers did their own reports on what had happened because they were And reading those reports it sounds like most of them I think they just realized they'd been impacted and rotated credentials I'm not really sure they actually lost any information as a result of this But these are four big companies and they have dedicated security teams I'm pretty sure and they're able to respond to things like this There would have been dozens hundreds of smaller companies that were much slower to respond and I suspect had a much worse time I do want to give CodeConf a fair bit of praise because they did immediately come out and tell people hey this has happened and tell them what they need to do to fix things and make sure it didn't get worse That being said I would have liked to have seen a bit more information on exactly what happened like why was there a secret in a Docker image and why didn't they notice the script had been modified But I can take a bit of a guess at what happened with the build secret or the Google Cloud secret One possibility is it was just in the build context and got copied into the image by Another possibility is it did something like this And I have seen this before Basically in Docker builds there's like a layered file system So although if I run this image I won't be able to get to my secret file but if you know what you're doing you can go back to higher layer and I can get to my secret file So if you ever do something like this you've actually exposed my secret file to anybody that has that What should you do instead Yeah you can do this if you want So you can use Docker build secrets and that will store it in a temporary file system and it never hits the image if you like But honestly the better idea is to try and keep secrets completely away from your Docker builds Oh and the third option is to squash the file system so there's only one layer But by far the best option is don't have the secrets there at all So I did do some investigation I went on to the Wayback Machine and Internet Archive and I looked at the actual script that they were telling people to use in GitHub And that's it here There's nothing too surprising We go right down to the bottom though and we do see this Trying to walk off the stage The bash pipe through curl command And this command does get There's a lot of this and it gets a bad rep And it's definitely not perfect I do have some issues with it I'd actually argue it's probably not the worst thing ever It is HTTPS so we are pretty sure that whatever we're downloading does come from CodeCov Like it's very hard to do a man in the middle attack here There isn't any sudo so at least we're not piping into sudo But yeah I'd really want to see a sort of checksum or a GPG check or some sort of verification of the integrity of the file I mean one question is just what happens if the transfer gets interrupted You know you'd be running half a script It doesn't wait until it downloads it all before it starts running it So not great If you do ever come across something that tells you to do things in a similar install fashion what I'd recommend is take apart the two steps So do your download and then do your execution You can also just take a look at the code Is it a good idea I accept you can't always be doing that One thing you can do though is add in a checksum or even a GPG check if it's supported And that will sort of alert you if the file ever changes And then you can go and check the changes in the file I took this example from the Docker Redis image So this is like the official build for the Redis image And you can see what happens when they download Redis They do check that it hasn't changed against a sort of checksum And that's basically how you can do that sort of GPG is a little bit more complicated But the nice thing about GPG is that I only need to do it once if you like And it will be signed with the same signature so I won't need to update this Whereas this check will need to be updated each time that checksum changes So GPG is a bit nicer And this is from the same file This time for the Gosu utility What I would say though is if you're distributing software so you have your own thing that you want people to download and use if you can use a package manager So let them get it from Homebrew or something similar Then that will take care of all the verification and so on If not one nice thing you can do is on your download site provide things like checksums and signatures like in your release page for example Next thing I want to talk about 12 Factor App Who's heard of the 12 Factor App Ah good So this is really seminal I love the 12 Factor App It was really important in how we started developing what we now call cloud native applications I guess But it does say this about storing config in the And it does even explicitly mention credentials to external services such as Amazon S3 or And I'd actually say that's not great advice And the reason is that environment variables are not designed to store secrets They were never meant to be private if you like I can just type env and I've dumped all the secrets out in plain text So they're just far too easily shared And they get printed in logs Like quite often somebody might ask for logs on a server or You type env and yeah it's only printed all your secrets So I would seriously try to avoid having things in environment variables What should you do instead Well the best one is not have those secrets at all See if you can use something like identity federation so you don't require that If you do need to use secrets use something like a secret manager The clouds all have them AWS has one Google But there are also things that for Kubernetes that's the external secret something And also Kubernetes directly supports having secret files which will use temporary volumes and stuff And still a much better way than environment variables Okay the second attack I want to talk about is change files So that's from this year back in March Change files was a pretty popular GitHub action And all it really did was tell you a list of the change files between two commits And the attackers pushed an update that meant that the action leaked secrets to logs with a little bit of obfuscation And then the attackers could then find the secrets and exploit them This affected the released version of the change files action So any user of the GitHub change files action that had not pinned to an older version had automatically exposed all their GitHub secrets to the runner Exposed all the GitHub secrets that the runner had And yeah that wasn't a lot of fun It affected a lot of organizations We actually used change files at ChainGuard We got lucky and I'll explain how in a And for a lot of people that I think was the main story about this Yeah people had a bad day and moved on But more details emerged over time and it kind of got even crazier And so the first question you probably would ask is how was the change files repo compromised Well assuming TGActions didn't mean to do this And the reason is that they had a dependency on another action called ReviewDog And ReviewDog runs link checks to check for adherence to things like coding standards And the ReviewDog action was also compromised In this case the compromise seems to have been a leaked access token There was one really odd thing about ReviewDog is they had a large number of approved contributors and they seemed to have this automated invite flow So if you worked on I think it was their plugins you could automatically become a which yeah that's probably a bad idea Don't give people automatic access to your GitHub Anyway it turns out the attacker managed to a personal access token for a ReviewDog contributor and used that and then did a similar attack to the one they would later do on changed files to compromise ReviewDog as in they dumped secrets into a and then you could then retrieve that file later Yeah and then you went and did the same thing to change files And so the next question you might ask is why did they do this What was the goal And I don't know how many users these actions had but the main ReviewDog repo has about 8 500 stars and changed files has about 2 500 stars So it's probably safe to say there's hundreds or of affected users between the two attacks So it kind of sounds like the point of the attack was to get as many credentials and secrets as possible right You're leaking secrets for hundreds of orgs Some of them are undoubtedly going to be slow to retake credentials and be potential victims You'd actually be wrong They're all every single one of them was collateral damage because there's only one single target Anybody want to Anybody know not too surprisingly it was Coinbase And so presumably the attackers had some great plan to steal millions in It was ultimately unsuccessful but just think about it from a supply chain POV So they didn't go after Coinbase head on They knew Coinbase's weakest link wasn't in their own security but instead of the security of their dependencies And they didn't even go after change files directly They went against after a vulnerability and when they've changed files So it was kind of sophisticated and at least so far as it kind of chained multiple things together And it definitely showed a level of The thing that really kind of annoys me though is they just didn't care about all the thousands of people that they affected I mean thousands and thousands of hours wasted dealing with the fallout from this The attacker didn't need to make everything public It was just the easiest way to get the secrets out One thing I should say is if you want to read more about this attack and I think most of the other attacks there's a few great resources like Wiz who have really good blogs and stuff but also Socket So go and check those ones So what could you do about this One thing that seems fairly obvious to be honest is verify contributors And although it seems obvious it's very hard to do I mean I can say don't have an automated workflow to add people to your GitHub but that's probably fairly obvious to be You can do things like enforce and commit sign in so everybody that contributes has to sign their commits And you can do things like run for checks for malware so all your PRs are checked for things like that But honestly it's very hard to vet people One attack that I nearly talked about was the XZ I won't say XZ but I guess it's XZ And the XZ one was interesting because they basically had a contributor who'd been contributing valid contributions for years I and then turned out to be presumably a nation state attacker I don't know what you do there Another thing you can do is restrict tag updates So that would have helped In this case I think the review dog one they changed a tag to point to the malicious commit or something And you can restrict tag updates by editing rule sets There's also a very handy page on GitHub I'll share these slides but basically there's a GitHub page that you can go through and it will check your recommended security config Pinning So you can set you can pin actions You've probably seen this with Docker images You can do something very similar with GitHub actions and you can pin to an exact version And that means you'll always use that exact version And if you did that you wouldn't have been immediately impacted by this attack The problem of course is you need to update that hash You want to stay up to date with the latest version so you're probably going to have some sort of automated workflow to update And that's what ChainGuard did and that's the reason we weren't impacted by this and we never actually updated to the malicious version But we did have Dependabot running so it would have updated us at some point and would we have seen it Maybe Maybe not Oh yeah Very similar thing for container images Honestly I think this is the biggest takeaway of the whole talk Please try and get rid of as many long lived credentials as you possibly can In every single attack basically long lived credentials have been a If you can use something like Identity Federation OIDC something like that Get rid of the secrets if at all possible If you can't try and use really short lived tokens You can do things like have a token that only lives for minutes and for the single call that you need for example And in GitHub's particular case we actually wrote something called OctoSTS that we used to get rid of personal access tokens in a few cases So you can go and check that out as well Okay the last incident I want to talk about was just from last month It's called Shai Halud And this was where like 500 NPM packages and associated GitHub repos were compromised And the attacker extracted secrets from the The big thing here was it had worm like behavior so that's why it's called Shai Halud Most of you are probably aware that worms in Dune are called the Shai Halud But also if you look at the source code they did name some stuff Shai Halud in the actual attack So that's where the name comes from But it was yeah it was kind of interesting Basically if you ran a compromised NPM package as well as trying to get the secrets out of your account it would also try to infect any NPM packages that you had the right to publish to And so what was happening was if you put it run it was like infecting further packages and it was escalating And so many people or so many packages got compromised that GitHub had to step in and take action and basically just they stopped accepting pushes with what they called IOC or Indicators of Compromise but yeah basically the hack script So one really interesting thing actually in all of these attacks is exfiltration because that actually tends to be a sticky point for the attackers How do they get the data out of the systems without exposing themselves So in the first case in the CodeCoff one they actually used a server they controlled I Now that's got a couple of drawbacks One is that's probably like a single IP address So that's quite easy to If it was DNS it can be blocked or taken over or And that stops the attack dead And the other thing is if you like control a there's a trail of breadcrumbs there that could potentially lead back to the So that's I think why you saw in the Change Files attack that they made everything public just because there's less exposure for the Even though other people could go and download the secrets they didn't really care Actually to be they did like encrypt them with Base64 but obviously that doesn't do much In this case they kind of did a little bit of both So they used TruffleHog actually to find all the secrets they could and then they sent them all to this like webhook So you've probably seen like webhook testing services Basically you can curl them and it'll print out all the arguments they were called with which is really handy for testing web services And so that's what they used I guess they would just go and look at the logs and pull out the secrets But the interesting thing was they were on the free tier and they actually got rate limited Which kind of sounds funny but then you realize the reason they're on the free tier is because they don't want to supply a credit card because that would lead back to them And also they actually were still exposing all the secrets because it was in the workflow log where you could see the call to And the other thing they did was they made private repos or they made public copies of private repos where they could Yeah and actually if you went and looked on GitHub and did a search for Shikaload at the time you would find all these 697 repos there that were presumably A few of these are just talking about the worm but the ones down here I think were actual compromised repositories that had private repos that were made into public copies with the Shikaload migration description So one other thing that I noticed from the GitHub response and the NPM response from this is that it appears that quite a few people published NPM and Cargo and PyPy and so on from the laptops Which sounds kind of crazy to me So if you're responsible for NPM or something like that packages please don't publish from your Set up a proper CICD workflow and do it from there I'm really surprised that people do that It just seems frankly a little bit unprofessional But also you're risking all your secrets on your laptop being exposed if something like this And yeah what you can do instead is use something called Trusted Publishing So this is relatively new And in the GitHub blog they talked about this So if you have NPM packages or also PyPy and Cargo support it look up Trusted Publishing Basically instead of using a long lived token what you do is you can set up in well I'll show you an So this is for PyPy What we can say is this GitHub action is allowed to publish packages to our PyPy So it kind of inverts the control a bit But it means you no longer have the need for this long lived secret in the GitHub action So it's one less thing to worry about Another thing I find interesting about this attack is they use TruffleHog Has anybody seen TruffleHog Yeah a few people So it's actually quite a nice tool It's really useful for defenders as well as attackers You can run it on your own code and it will show you any places that you might be exposing secrets that you didn't mean to So you can run it on Docker images or VMs or any environment And yeah I recommend you think about running something like that because otherwise the attackers will do it for you MFA Hopefully I don't really need to explain what MFA is You can enforce that on org level though So you might want to go into your GitHub orgs and say everybody has to use MFA and do think about buying keys It's a little bit faster than Google Authenticator etc Okay I think I'm getting close in time I was going to do I'm going to share these slides with you I The big one I want you to take away is avoid long lived credentials Like of all the tips I think that's by far the most important one Try and get rid of as many long lived credentials as I do also have some tooling here that I'll let you go through the slides for What I want to end with though is this kind of sobering quote from a ransomware hacker And what he said was if all ransomware groups suddenly became cyber security specialists and those who are cyber security specialists start pen testing the ransomware would end So basically the defenders can't do what the attackers can but the attackers can do the defenders And I sort of want you to think about that for a It's pretty scary if you ask me But what I hope is that this talk has gone just a little bit of the way towards addressing that balance And that you've seen some of the ways in which attacks work and that you have some practical steps to address them Okay that was it Thank you very much
